This is normally held at the house of the boy. A marriage held at the girl's house or officiated over by a Brahmin would be called Diku Aandi, 2) elopement by mutual consent of the couple, usually referred to as Kepea, 3) holding back a girl visiting a village to be the wife of a man of the village, referred to as sasaṅ-uraa, 4) taking a girl from e.g. a feast or a market without her previous consent, referred to as Opor-Tipić.

a ceremony by which a wife newly brought to her husband’s house is initiated into cooking the meal for the family. A sacrifice usually of a chicken is made after which an offering is made to the ancestors in the Adiṅ to get their blessing on the new wife. Until this is done the new wife may not enter the Adiṅ nor touch the Manḍi Chaṭu. After this she cooks her first meal to which all those to whom she must show special respect are invited so that she may recognize them; to initiate a newly brought wife by this ceremony

to say; to reflect (N.B. men as distinct from kaji often has this interior meaning, e.g. jibonreko menena, 'they reflect within their spirits'). English indirect discourse can be translated as follows - - gapale hućoḱako men ket́a, 'they said that they would come tomorrow'. (The exact words spoken are used followed by the required form of the verb men, Les. 35, 36). Men is not used when in English we have an indirect object, 'to say to ...'; in that case meta, q.v. would be used. When meaning 'say instead of a full verb form merely the root men is used 1) when quoting replies made by some third person, e.g. Kań hhućoḱać men, 'He says that he will not come' or 2) when emphasizing one's own words, e.g., Kań senoḱaań men, 'I say that I will not go' (after having already Said it and the hearer did not hear or insisted to the contarary); The passive form menoḱ is used meaning 'to be said', 'to be called something, e.g. nena chikana; menoḱaa, 'what is this called?', but it is also used meaning 'to say or reflect to one's advantage'; men is also used in the same way as menteaḱ or mena instead of mente, 'that' (following direct discourse) when the word for saying is a noun, e.g. Haturen kuiko kako paeṭia men kajido banoḱa, 'The fact is not that village women do not work'

subwords.sub_definition: to tell beforehand (unlike men this can take an -a aspect marker, e.g. men-ayeraḍkoać, ‘He told them beforehand’)

to be present, exist, be home; with an inan. subject the form menaḱ is used, with animate subj. forms, the forms menaḱńa. etc. are used (see Les. 18 and 36); to have (in certain constructions, Les. 21); used as a participle/adjective as in the examples given here, esu Baba-Biti menaḱ Oaḱ, ‘a house having much wealth’, Koahon mit́hoo ge menaḱć Oaḱ, 'a house in which there is only one son', sangi Hon ko menaḱko Oaḱ, 'a house in which there are many children' (See Les. 18)

subwords.sub_definition: to already be

an adjectival form modifying an animate noun and meaning either 1) being present (after a form ending in -re, ‘in’, e.g. Ote re menaḱtan Nage ko, ‘Nage spirits present in a field’) or 2) ‘having’, ‘possessing’, e.g. Poesa menaḱtan sepeet́ ko, ‘young men having money’. from menaḱtan noun forms are formed, (sg.) menaḱtanić, (dl.) menaḱtankin, (pl.) menaḱtanko, e.g. Ote re menaḱtanić, ‘the one (anim.) on the ground’, bugin Sal Ote ko menaḱtanko, ‘those having good low fields’

1) an adjectival form modifying an inanimate noun with usage the same as given under menaḱtan (which is used with animate nouns), e.g. Baba menaḱ teaḱ Muṭi, ‘a sheaf which has paddy grains on it’; 2) a noun form menaḱteaḱ in the sing. and menaḱ teaḱko in the pl. meaning ‘that which is present or possessed’
to be from earlier times, e.g. of some custom which has come down

the voice marker for the passive voice in the simple (without aspect markers) future and related tenses (Les. 8). The reciprocal infix (the reciprocal of any verb can be formed by infixing the reciprocal marker -p- after the first vowel of a verb root and then repeating that vowel after the -p-. If this first vowel is long, it retains its long quality only after the -p- infix (Les. 23); a -p- infix is also used in a few superlatives, e.g. máparaṅ, hupuḍiń, jipiliń; also a -p- infix is used in a few terms implying relationship, e.g. eperate, 'his wife', hopon, sepēt́ (prob. from sēt́ as in hon sēt́)

The reciprocal infix (the reciprocal of any verb can be formed by infixing the reciprocal marker -p- after the first vowel of a verb root and then repeating that vowel after the -p-. If this first vowel is long, it retains its long quality only after the -p- infix (Les. 23); a -p- infix is also used in a few superlatives, e.g. máparaṅ, hupuḍiń, jipiliń; also a -p- infix is used in a few terms implying relationship, e.g. eperate, 'his wife', hopon, sepēt́ (prob. from sēt́ as in hon sēt́)

(in a few expressions -ko is used of one person to show respect, e.g. héyarko, ‘father-in-law’ said by his daughter-in-law); in verb forms it indicates a pl. animate sub. and/or obj. A -ko marker is often added to a noun to include other like objects and to verbs to include other lke actions (Les. 37). to hang down long and loose, e.g. a vine, long fruit, a snake hanging from a tree

a ground bird which reputedly makes its nest with the opening facing the direction from which heavy rain will not come. Some say that there are two types according to how they make the nest, one type, called guyu lipi, makes a kind of dome (kumba) (prob. the Bush Lark, some of whom make domed nests), and a second type, called hasa lipi, makes a nest of earth (prob. the Indian Small Skylark)
to fly in the breeze (sometimes used parallel to hoyo(leka))

subwords.sub_definition: to fly in the breeze, e.g a flag

definition: to experience a palpitation or throbbing of the heart due to fear (e.g. kuameć lipir eana, or Jivć lipir eana, His heart beat fast out of fear'

subwords.sub_definition: the same of a continued action; to fly in the breeze,e.g. a flag (lipi-lipi is prob. more common for this second meaning)

definition: a deep set fear; apprehension; to feel the same
of branches, to wave e.g. from the wind or from a weight on them

subwords.sub_definition: same as līr of a continued or repeated action

definition: to wear one's dhoti, loin cloth, waist cloth, or sari hanging low (also lindar lopor)
of vines, fruit, beans, ramba, etc., to hang long and thin
to pull (bend) a branch toward oneself

subwords.sub_definition: to pull a branch toward oneself e.g. in order to pluck fruit

definition: of a mother hen, to have the feathers standing up all over the body; of a person, to have his hair in disarray (cf. silsil and chúṭia of a fighting cock, to have feathers sticking up on the neck)
experiencing (or 'due to') intense itching (usuallly with verb gotaḱn, ‘to scratch oneself’)

the small particles which remain on the fingers or which fall on the ground when eating; to defile or pollute (by touching with hands on which there is lita, or by the touch of someone socially unclean); pass. to be defiled or polluted; to be treated in a disrespectful way

subwords.sub_definition: watery substance remaining from one's meal

definition: the youngest child in a family
to form a paste (e.g. rain forming a muddy paste of soil); to have e.g. one's hand smeared in some paste
to become very soft (esp. the feet) by being in water for a long time
a very slight (scarcely perceptible) heart-beat, e.g. ayaḱ kuamre miat́ ô liṭiṕ banoḱa, ‘In his chest no heart-beat is perceived’

subwords.sub_definition: to have a very slight beating of the heart e.g. because of of fear (less than ḍiṕ-ḍib), of one's breath, to come very faintly or weakly (e.g. of a dying baby)

definition: to wave e.g a bird's tail (usually used in the repeated form)

subwords.sub_definition: the same of a continued or repeated action
the Grey Wagtail (bird), also called danḍet́ siraḱ, (see siraḱ)

definition: to bend; to bend down with weight (e.g. a branch with much fruit, one side of a scale with weight upon it); pliable
to burn; pass. to be set on fire

subwords.sub_definition: to burn until dawn
to burn the whole night
to burn brown by being suspended over a fire in a house.
of a fire, to reach by burning
to drive out by burning; to burn out (e.g. some impurity)
to kill by burning
to burn so as to char
by burning, to make shrink or become wrinkled, esp. of certain types of cloth, of human flesh, of leaves
pogo by burning to cause some swelling and perhaps some open wound
to finish off by burning
to find by burning, e.g. some najom by burning the body of a dead person (the part affected by the najom will not burn)
to purify by fire
to be engulfed in flames and one's body badly burned
to leave a part remaining after burning (something)
to partially burn

definition: with, together with (a postposition indicating accompaniment, Les. 33)
covetousness; to covet (better Ho would be haya)
to dilute a thick mass (e.g. of soil or of some grain) with a liquid so that particles of the mass float about in the liquid
an elephant's trunk, a pig's snout
same as locha, q.v.
longer on one side or part than another (used in form lochogeya or lochoakana)

subwords.sub_definition: not properly proportioned, longer on one side than another, e.g. a bed, a table, a field (a jingle of locho)

the day dedicated to the Hindu goddess, Lakshmi, Thursday. It is believed that a girl should not leave her home to go to be married on that day (apparently lest the goddess also transfer the wealth of the girl's family to the new house to which she is going) (the commonly used word for Thursday is gurbar)

definition: of a plant, bush, etc., to grow fully, giving leaves in profusion (also lidaṕ-lodob)

subwords.sub_definition: same as lodob(leka)

definition: of people or animals, together in a large group
a level place on the top of a hill
the male organ, penis (mage kaji)

of a part of something, to hang loose or bulge over to one side (used e.g. of a side of a leaf-cup hanging over allowing the contents to fall out, or of the head of a baby drooped over to one side, or of a part of a bundie bulging over to one side)
to make an opening e.g. in one's clothes, a rice bale, a leaf porom, exposing some inner surface; pass to have an opening exposing some inner surface
to swell up, e.g. burnt skin, a sore, a wound
to murmur
-same as logo-pogo, q.v. (also lugur-pugur)
to bite into with wide open mouth, e.g. of a dog or tiger (used of men when scolding or ridiculing)
to fall, topple over (of people, animals)
lame; to limp

subwords.sub_definition: to limp along (usually used with-te and verb sen)

definition: same as mã lokin, q.v.
to turn up the lips when about to cry
hot; to make hot; to feel hot (Les. 26); of one's spirit, to be hot with anger, of a spirit (bonga), to cause someone so have a high fever (see umbae)

subwords.sub_definition: a time of the day or part of the year when it is especially hot
to spoil by overheat ing e.g. milk (see golgol)
freshly cooked (and therefore hot) rice, also called roka manḍi (as distinct from basi manḍi or daḱ manḍi)
extreme (steaming) heat

definition: to hold one's mouth partly open with the lower lip protruding, e.g. when pouting
of a beard, to be long and bushy (used esp. In stories, sometimes used in joking)
of paddy stalks, to fall over before the grain is properly formed because too top-heavy (due sometimes to putting too much fertilizer)

to deceive (used esp. of deceiving by words. The term londor-pondor lekan ho would mean a person who so deceives. It could also be used of one who tarries overlong idly chatting at some place where rice-beer is being served to guests)
of a baby, to suck the mother's milk; of a person, to drink very slowly; of one smoking, to smoke very slowly

subwords.sub_definition: the same of a continued action

definition: to roam about at leisure
rice fields in a ravine or valley

subwords.sub_definition: following the course of low-lying rice fields

definition: of things such as straw, sheaves of paddy, which are piled up, for those on top to slip (slide) down the side
Sri Lanka; a great distance
a small hollow or cavity e.g. in a wall or under a stone (such that a bird could go for shelter)
to reduce to dust, to pulverize; of a path, to be thick with dust, e.g. from many people walking on it
a clearance in a jungle (a level opening where fields can be made between two hills)
a heavily wooded area where water also springs up, esp. inside the jungle, but could be near a village, e.g. in the desauli
long-limbed and strong
buru a hill a few miles west of Kharsawan village
a ravine cut out by running waters lor Gaḍa a stream running through a ravine

subwords.sub_definition: a collective noun for low hollowed-out terrain
a collective noun for ravines and valleys

definition: of the lips, esp. the upper one, to be swollen out, e.g after a wasp's bite or as a permanent feature
to hold the lips slightly extended, e.g. of one about to cry, of one pouting, or of one in deep gloom (e.g. because hungry)
same as lorka
to lie in wait for; to spy on

subwords.sub_definition: to lie in wait for

definition: to speak in an almost unintellible way (more common than this would be laṛor-baṛor, q.v.)
to buckle at the knees and fall
thick wet mud; to spatter or cover with wet mud; by ploughing to make fields into soft liquidy mud for transplating (compare jobe, ḍobe)

subwords.sub_definition: to cover with wet mud

definition: the sound made by leaves being strongly shaken on a branch (either while still on a tree, or after having been cut from the tree being shaken by someone e.g. in merriment)
to buckle at the knees and fall (also loseć)
chilly dampness; to feel the same; to be damp (e.g. a wall), to be affected by frost, (e.g. leaves)

subwords.sub_definition: a malarial condi- tion brought on by dampness and coldness
at times of chilly dampness (e.g. in the early morning due to dew)
same as losom hasu

definition: loose, e.g. of rice bundles not tightly tied; of one's body, flabby)
a note (currency)
straw in long sheaves after threshing, to make into the same
to stick to (of something which can be washed off such as mud, blood, bird droppings, etc.)
dosora the dosora feast held yearly in the village Lota
a sprain, pass. to suffer a sprain
a lottery

subwords.sub_definition: a lottery held at a sim paṛa (to induce more people to attend the one who runs the cock-fight puts up a cock along with some other prize, such as a cloth, for anyone who can defeat his cock)

definition: a plant about 2 ft. high whose deep coloured leaves give off a pleasant odour, prob. Ocimum basilicum, L., Labiatae, B.106/16, H.106/1/2, (This is called ḍimbu Bah (q.v.) in the Sonua area)
a fig tree, Ficus glomerata, Roxb., B. 125/9, H.125/8/24 Moraceae
to soak in water in order to soften, e.g. leaves; to add water e.g. to some powder, mud, etc. to make a paste
Daru a tree much like the bēl tree, but with less tasty fruit, see bēl Daru
to dissolve completely in water
the gurić porob (q.v) of the mage feast

subwords.sub_definition: the same as loyo poroṕ

definition: a harmless snake

subwords.sub_definition: another name for loyoṅ biṅ
a kind of mushroom

definition: to ladle (more common near Chaibasa is buraḱ)
to allure, entice, win over by flattery or by some gift, etc. (also labuḱ)
gluttonous, e.g. lucha-lekan hō, 'a glutton’
to have something protruding out of e.g. a bundle; to have a painful protruding of a vein of the anus as in haemorrhoids (sambe hasu)

subwords.sub_definition: to have one's eye or eyes bulging out (of one with a physical defect, or used in scolding of one who stares with big eyes, see also lenḍekeć met́)

definition: to bulge out (e.g. for one part of a rice bale to bulge out); the scrotum of goats and smaller animals
in a group or flock, e.g. of men or birds, esp. as seen from a distance; giving off a deep rumbling sound, e.g. of thunder clouds (for this lidi-lidi is also used)

subwords.sub_definition: of men or animals, moving together in a group (with verbs of motion. For a static group mi guṭi would be used.)

definition: of an animal, e.g. a bear, to have long thick hair on its body

subwords.sub_definition: same as ludum(leka)

definition: a disease in which the body is swollen by fluids, dropsy
a bird's nest (cf. also tuka, busu, of a bird, to make a nest
an alternate, less common form of Lungam, silkworm

the sucking action of a baby drinking the mother's milk

a cooking vessle of brass or copper

same as mã lukin, q.v.

subwords.sub_definition: of old people walking along, bent at the knees

names given in some stories to the first man and woman (see also Luṭukum haṛam, Luṭukum buṛi)
to quake with fear

same as lulu-lulu(tan), figur. to be scared stiff, e.g. (borote) lulu-puchu-chaba eanae, He was completely scared stiff
to make wet, pass. -to become wet

swollen, esp. of the lips, can also refer to a piles-like swelling
a place in a thick jungle where light does not pen etrate well and where one tends to feel fear

to spread out using a cloth e.g. diluted cow-dung (cf. jalom, to spread with the hand)

subwords.sub_definition: ladleful; one ladle

an inedible suku (gourd) from which ladles are made

definition: soul. Every man has a Jiv and a Rva. The Jiv is the principle of life. When this goes a man dies. The Rva of a man does not die. While a man is still alive his Rva can leave his body and move around, e.g. when he is dreaming or at time of near death or sickness (see Rva keya-uraa). When a man dies his Rva leaves the body and later is called into the adiń of his family in the kea-ader ceremony

subwords.sub_definition: soul-killing, mortal(sin)

to call back a man's Rva which has left his body prior to death. Used in two cases - - 1) for a man who is near death or apparently dead, sometimes a Dẽoa will make efforts to call back into his body his Rva which perhaps is hiding in some nearby deep water, etc. 2) for a man who has physically recovered from sickness but is still weak and restless (Jiv ka sukuića) or mentally disturbed, divination or sacrifices are performed to recall his Rva, which is believed to still be roaming apart from the body, back into the body
water placed in a maṭia in a room into which the Rva of a dead person is being called in a kea-ader ceremony.
